Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that New York City is set to ban hot dogs and processed meats, when in reality, it is only reducing the purchase of processed meats in government-run facilities.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or sources to back up the statement.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that banning hot dogs and processed meats will effectively combat climate change, without providing any evidence or explanation for this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim, as the reduction of processed meat consumption in New York City is part of a broader strategy to promote healthy living and community well-being, not solely focused on combating climate change.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that hot dogs are not being banned city-wide, as restaurants, hot-dog stands, grocery stores, and other privately owned businesses will still be able to sell hot dogs.
Understate: The claim may understate the actual scope of the measures taken by New York City, as it focuses solely on hot dogs and processed meats, without mentioning other initiatives included in the "Green New Deal" or "OneNYC 2050" strategy.
